snippet: The United States slashed its estimate of the annual corn crop by 15.5 percent, to its lowest level since 1995, with the cost of processed food, animal feed and ethanol likely to rise.
abstract: United States, dealing with the worst drought in fifty years, slashes estimate of the annual corn crop to its lowest level since 1995, and soybeans and other crops are expected to have similar low yields; retailers say they do not expect to have to pass along price increases to customers in the short term, but analysts say prices could rise 20 to 25 percent down the road.

byline.original: By RON NIXON and ANNIE LOWREY
byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by Adam Nossiter in Dakar, Senegal; Rick Gladstone in New York; and John Eligon in Kansas City, Mo.

lead_paragraph: The United States slashed its estimate of the annual corn crop by 15.5 percent, to its lowest level since 1995, with the cost of processed food, animal feed and ethanol likely to rise.

headline.main: Drought Forces Reductions in U.S. Crop Forecasts
headline.print_headline: Drought Forces Reductions in Crop Forecasts
